awd_abstract_narration:
This program will upgrade the existing camera on the Atacama Cosmology Telescope in Chile to incorporate new multi-color pixels in large detector arrays at five frequencies, and develop instrumentation to allow wide area measurements of cosmic microwave background (CMB) polarization.   This Advanced ACTPol (AdvACT) system will answer questions about the first moments of the universe, the properties of its contents, the formation of structures under the influence of gravity, and the nature of dark energy.  In terms of broader impacts, the project will focus on three areas: training graduate and undergraduate students in AdvACT and related science, informing the public, and enhancing the STEM pipeline of students from underrepresented groups through outreach projects.   Students and postdoctoral researchers will be involved in the design, assembly, and testing of the new detector arrays. Two summer schools will be hosted coincident with major data releases to train graduate students and postdocs in deriving science from the data. In collaboration with the Franklin Institute, team members will co-produce a new cosmology program and deliver shows at various planetariums. Special efforts will be made to extend research opportunities to undergraduates from groups underrepresented in STEM fields.  

The AdvACT intensity and polarization maps of the CMB will 1) overlap the entire Large Synoptic Survey Telescope (LSST) survey as well as other surveys not accessible from the South Pole; 2) have excellent resolution of order one arcminute (depending on frequency); 3) span 25-280 GHz in five bands, essential for the removal of Galactic foregrounds; and 4) have the spatial dynamic range to detect large-angular-scale signatures of inflation at one end, and galaxy clusters and dusty galaxies at the other.  AdvACT will perform a large-area survey to search for gravitational waves generated during inflation (B-modes), and measure the isotropy, frequency spectrum, and scale dependence of any detected signal.  Measurements of primary CMB fluctuations will improve our knowledge of key cosmological parameters, and measurements of secondary fluctuations will map out the dark matter distribution, potentially providing the first high-signal-to-noise measurement of the sum of the neutrino masses.  In addition, AdvACT maps will contain measurements of approximately 20,000 clusters of galaxies via the Sunyaev-Zeldovich Effect, with heightened scientific impact due to overlap of the survey with X-ray and optical surveys such as eROSITA, the Dark Energy Survey, and LSST. AdvACT millimeter-wavelength source lists will provide many thousands of targets for study by ALMA.  The program will deliver a number of astronomy community benefits, including public maps, assistance to other teams, and free sharing of technology techniques.

por.por_cntn:
Context

The Atacama Cosmology Telescope (ACT) mapped the sky at microwave frequencies for 15 years.  The maps convey information from the earliest instants of our universe, via patterns in the cosmic microwave background (CMB) emanating from the first few hundred thousand years after the big bang, which carry imprints of the history of the universe up until then.   

Scientific Aims

Prior measurements of the CMB were central in establishing the standard cosmological model, which describes the primordial universe and its subsequent evolution with only six fundamental parameters.  It posits that the massive objects populating the universe around us - galaxies with hundreds of billions of stars each, with central black holes and embedded in huge halos of dark matter - grew by gravitational collapse from tiny initial overdensities in the distribution of matter in the primordial universe.   The work funded by this award focused on addressing some of the remaining profound questions including:  what generated those tiny initial seeds for galaxies?  Why is the expansion of the universe accelerating?    How did galaxies form and evolve?   What is the dark matter, and how is it related to the luminous matter?    

Key Accomplishments

This award outfitted ACT with a new camera,  Advanced ACTPol.  The camera operated in five frequency bands, from 25 to 280 GHz, and its observations were used to make huge maps of not only the CMB temperature, but also its polarization, covering 40% of the celestial sphere.  The resulting maps are unmatched in their combination of sensitivity, angular resolution, and area. They cover the area that the Vera Rubin Observatory plans to map.  They complement the Planck and WMAP satellite maps (which cover the entire sphere) with increased angular resolution and sensitivity.  This award also supported scientific analysis of the maps, and analysis of earlier ACT data on subsections of the full map area.

The Advanced ACTPol camera was the most sensitive ground-based CMB receiver in the world for much of its operating life, in part due to the use of a cryogen-free  dilution refrigerator to cool the transition-edge-sensor bolometer detectors to 0.1 K, and in part due to the high yield and good performance of the large and dense detector arrays, developed under this award, and fabricated at NIST. 

Scientific Results

More than 70 peer-reviewed papers were published as a result of this award. Some focus on early universe parameters, making the important finding that the cosmology described by the fully independent ACT plus WMAP is the same to exquisite detail as that described by Planck.  Some papers consider model extensions, including those that might explain the `Hubble tension,`  the disagreement on how big the acceleration of the universe is today.  Some  of the papers examine the `growth rate of structure`, or how quickly massive objects formed from the initial small overdensities measured in the CMB.  The rate depends on the expansion history of the universe, on the correctness of general relativity at enormous length scales,  and on how much dark matter exists, among other things. Many of these studies use the large-area CMB lensing maps published under this award (see figure), in combination with data from other large federally-funded projects, including DESI, DES and BOSS. Other papers explore the evolution of galaxies, while others provide mass calibrations for the many thousands of clusters detected in the ACT maps.  (ACT has discovered more  clusters than all other CMB observatories combined.)  Other publications report on advances in instrumentation, and in analysis methods for CMB data.  ACT gave us the first measurements of the kinematic SZ effect (tracing the movement of galaxy clusters) and of CMB lensing, showed that the `missing baryons`  are in the outskirts of galaxy clusters, surveyed mm-wave transient sources, and pioneered numerous experimental and computational techniques now foundational in experimental cosmology.

Broader Impacts

The data products created under this award have been made publicly available, primarily through the NASA LAMBDA site.  Earlier ACT data sets have also been made public, and we intend to make future ACT data products public as well.  The public data products from this award include  multi-frequency maps, component-separated maps, lensing maps, cluster catalogs, source and transient information, and products needed to effectively use the maps, including calibration information, covariance matrices and noise simulations.

This award has provided training and mentoring for 29 undergraduate students, 35 graduate students, and 18 postdocs (of whom 11 began as graduate students with the project).   A major focus of the award was training people outside the ACT collaboration in using ACT data, while also providing general training in CMB analysis methods, in a series of three summer schools.  These activities were in addition to a broad program of outreach to the public, including public talks, meetings with elementary school classrooms, Science on Tap, interviews, and more talks.
